Award.AwardTitle: Nanoimprinting Ultrafiltration Membranes for Non-Chemical Fouling Mitigation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264276
Ding

The performance of ultrafiltration (UF) membranes used for liquid separations is often degraded by membrane fouling. The foulants can be partially removed by harsh chemical treatment, causing more energy consumption, loss of productivity, and shortened membrane lifetime. Thus, mitigation of membrane fouling remains a grand challenge for most liquid separation applications. While most antifouling strategies focus on modifying the surface chemistry of the UF membrane, this project aims to use micro and nanoscale patterns on UF membranes as a non-chemical approach to mitigate fouling during active filtration. To achieve this goal, the two specific objectives are: (1) to understand the processing ? structure ? performance relationships for creating patterns onto asymmetric porous UF membranes using nanoimprint lithography (NIL), without sacrificing the permselectivity of the membrane; and (2) to understand the mechanism of how these surface patterns affect fouling of the membranes during filtration. The PIs expect to advance current understanding of how surface topography affects fouling during active filtration. NIL will be applied to create patterns on the surface of the asymmetric UF membrane without sacrificing its permselectivity. Membranes with micro or nanopatterned surface have not been previously been fabricated. The NIL approach is applicable to all UF membranes, thus offering a platform for quantitative physico-chemical insights into the interplay between chemistry and topography on colloidal interactions in complex systems. The comparison of fouling between patterned and flat membranes with identical chemistry will shed light on the explicit role of surface topography on membrane fouling. The integration of lithographic patterns with the filtration membranes will allow the PIs to control the thermodynamic and hydrodynamic interactions between the membrane surface and the feed solution during active filtration. Broader impacts. Results of the project may guide a flexible non-chemical approach to produce UF membranes with reduced fouling and improved energy efficiency with benefits for a broad range of separation technologies. Results of the project will advance our current knowledge on how surface topography affects the membrane fouling during active filtration, which in turn will guide the design of surface patterns for targeting specific separation applications. The proposed educational impact will leverage the exceptional infrastructures for innovation in education and outreach at the University of Colorado to provide new, inspirational educational experiences, with a focus on membrane technology, for students at all levels. Other activities will enhance professional development of graduate students, promote diversity in science and engineering disciplines, and enhance K-12 outreach. The ultimate educational outcome of this proposal is to provide the essential membrane-science focused education to students at all levels, and encourage them to pursue careers in scientific disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymeric separation membranes are of critical importance to address the rising challenges in water treatment as well as energy-efficient separations of chemical and high-value pharmaceutical compounds.  Membrane-based technologies, compared with alternative separation technologies, have the advantages of low footprint and relatively low energy cost.  Fouling is the single most important problem affecting the performance and thus economics of the membrane technology.  As the permeate (e.g. water) transport through the membrane under pressure, the rejected solutes are concentrated and deposited on the membrane surfaces.  Membrane fouling increases the resistance to permeation and the frequency of cleaning, which increases the energy costs for the separation process and reduces the membrane lifetime.  Given the importance of this problem, tremendous efforts have been spent on improving the antifouling performances of these membranes.  However, many novel chemical-based approaches have not been successfully translated to practical applications because of their limitations in scalability, reliability, and cost. 

The aim of this project is to develop a new type of antifouling membranes by creating well-defined surface topography atop current commercial membranes, inspired by the antifouling skins of many creatures such as sharks.  All current commercial membranes have flat surfaces with random roughness resulted from the membrane formation process.  The approach we developed was to use nanoimprint lithography (NIL) to mechanically emboss sub-micron patterns atop commercial porous ultrafiltration (UF) membranes.  The research work focused on both understanding the NIL-based patterning process and the effects of the surface patterns on the antifouling performance of the patterned UF membranes.  The main accomplishments achieved are summarized below.

·        For the first time, we demonstrated that successful patterning of porous polymer membranes can be achieved using NIL, with feature size ranging from 100 nanometers to several micrometers.  The NIL-patterning process can be applied to all UF and microfiltration (MF) membranes, regardless of the chemistry of the membranes.  For example, membranes made of both semi-crystalline polymers (e.g. Polyacrylonitrile, Polyvinylidene fluoride or Cellulose acetate) and glassy polymers (e.g. Polyethersulfone, or Polysulfone) can be successfully patterned with this method.  This allows this method to be applied to already-optimized membrane chemistry for different applications.   

·        Our comprehensive experimental and theoretical studies revealed that the mechanism that governs the NIL-patterning process is the porosity-induced membrane plasticity.  The mechanical responses of the UF membranes under the patterning process can be quantitatively described by open-cell foam models.  The impact of deformation (occurred during the NIL process) on the permeability of the membranes can also be described by relationships developed for open-cell foams.  Such understanding allows us to optimize the NIL-process to create surface patterns on different porous membranes including UF membranes without sacrificing the permselective performance of the membranes. 

·        The presence of the surface patterns can effectively increase the antifouling performance of the UF membranes during cross-flow filtrations, i.e. when the feed solution flows parallel to the membrane surfaces.  This pattern-induced antifouling effect is attributed to the hydrodynamic interactions between feed solution and the patterned membrane surface.  More specifically, the presence of the patterns enhances the shear gradient (force) at the feed/membrane interface, which will lead to faster back-diffusion of the foulants.  This hydrodynamic effect increases with increase the Reynolds number (or the flow rate) of the feed flow, pattern heights, and the angle between the flow and pattern orientation.  The understanding allows us to design more effective antifouling surface patterns.

·        The surface-patterned UF membranes can be further used as support to fabricate reverse osmosis (RO) membranes with patterned surfaces.  This new type of RO membranes can be used to desalinate seawater with reduced scaling.

 The most significant outcome of this project is that we established a reliable method to fabricate patterned porous membranes.  This type of membranes is new and have improved antifouling performance during pressure-driven separation processes.  We disseminated the research results through several publications in top journals of the membrane field and conferences, which has attracted significant interests.  Two patent applications are currently under review, and one is exclusively licensed to a private company.  The broader impacts of the project lie in several areas: (1) potential economic impact through technological application of such surface-patterned membranes, in areas of desalination, wastewater treatment, and bioseperation.  (2) training of workforce at levels ranging from postdoctoral researchers, Ph.D students, undergraduate and high school students, which is crucial for maintaining the leadership of US in research and technological developments under an increasingly competitive international environment.
